page.title: 15ECOLOGY_WILDLIFE,WILTSHIRE
page.content: The fields, banks and hedgerows support many forms of wildlife. Rabbits are becoming more common in the countryside once again having survived their "near extermination" by myxomatosis in recent years. The entrance holes to the warrens can be clearly seen in the banks bordering the farm tracks and lanes. Fortunately they have not yet multiplied enough to become a nuisance to farmers again. Badgers can also be seen in the area and their setts are at present left alone by those who feel that they can spread disease. Foxes are fairly prevalent but are not hunted across this land. Many wild birds nest here and the song of the skylark can be heard way above on summer days
